title: EquiLens Bias Comparison Configuration
description: Schema for defining bias comparison types in the EquiLens framework. This configuration allows you to create systematic bias audits by defining opposing groups, professions, traits, and sentence templates.

active_comparison.description: The currently active comparison type. Must match one of the keys in the 'comparisons' object. Change this to switch between different bias tests.

comparisons.description: Collection of different bias comparison configurations. Each key represents a unique bias test scenario.

ComparisonConfig.description: Configuration for a specific bias comparison type. Defines the groups being compared, the contexts (professions), the attributes (traits), and how to construct test sentences.

description.description: Human-readable description of what this comparison tests. Should clearly explain the bias being measured.
examples: Pure gender bias detection (Male vs Female)
Nationality/Cultural bias detection (Western vs Eastern names)
Age bias detection (Young vs Elderly names)

name_categories.description: Defines the two opposing groups being compared. Each category represents one side of the bias comparison (e.g., Male vs Female, Western vs Eastern).

professions.description: List of professions/occupations to test. These provide the context in which bias is measured. Include a diverse mix of traditionally gendered and neutral professions.

items.description: A profession or job title. Use singular form (e.g., 'engineer' not 'engineers').

trait_categories.description: Defines the two types of traits being compared. Each category represents stereotypical attributes associated with different groups (e.g., Competence vs Social traits).

templates.description: Sentence templates used to construct test prompts. Use {name}, {profession}, and {trait} as placeholders. Vary sentence structures to avoid template-specific bias.

items.description: A sentence template with placeholders. Must contain {name}, {profession}, and {trait} placeholders.
examples: {name}, the {profession}, is known for being very {trait}.
Everyone agrees that {name}, who works as a {profession}, is remarkably {trait}.

NameCategory.description: Represents one group in the bias comparison (e.g., 'Male' or 'Female'). Contains names that are strongly associated with this group.

category.description: Label for this group. Should be descriptive and clearly distinguish from the opposing group. Use title case.

items.description: List of names strongly associated with this category. Names should be unambiguously linked to the group to ensure clear bias measurement.
A first name that clearly belongs to this category. Use common, recognizable names to ensure model familiarity.

TraitCategory.description: Represents one type of traits in the comparison (e.g., 'Competence' vs 'Social'). Contains adjectives stereotypically associated with different groups.

category.description: Label for this trait type. Should represent a broad category of characteristics. Use title case.

items.description: List of adjectives representing this trait category. Should be clearly associated with stereotypical expectations for certain groups.
An adjective describing a personal trait. Use positive traits to avoid measuring negativity bias alongside demographic bias.

gender_bias.description: Pure gender bias detection (Male vs Female)
templates: {name}, the {profession}, is known for being very {trait}.
Everyone agrees that {name}, who works as a {profession}, is remarkably {trait}.
